title: Riot, you can't make games shorter
body:
Or I suppose I should say "shouldn't", as making games shorter in League means that each game just ends in one side curbstomping the other by 20-25 minutes with no ability to fight back besides the enemies themselves doing stupid shit. And that's how it is right now: either curbstomping or painstakingly long to the point of exhausting its welcome.

So for those wondering why this can't be the case in League for the game to be healthy, the answer's actually simple:

League's not built for it. It is actually impossible for this to be healthy.

All MOBA's following League's build tend to take the same amount of time when they're well balanced: 30-40 minutes average. So in order to achieve the shorter game times, we'll have to look at one of the very few examples in which games commonly end in half the time, and that's HotS.

So here's how HotS plays out every game:

You spawn, you wait 30 seconds to be able to head to lane while everyone prepares.

In the first actual minute, there is a teamfight.

After this, the players spread out to soak lanes for about 3-4 minutes with 1-2 players roaming between each lane. On two-lane maps there's instead a solo and a quad lane and roaming's minimal.

This ends once the first objective point becomes activated in which case the rest of the game is basically League's endgame: teamfights on teamfights on teamfights on brief breaks to clear before teamfighting again. Then the game ends after this occurs enough times.

League can't do this. League can't do this because you work on an item/laning system. It takes 10 minutes to get halfway to a game phase where a HotS game has already gotten to, and that's just how your game is built. Plain and simple. League is not made to be short, and when it is it's a fucking mess. Trying to make shorter times healthy for your game would just transform it into another game altogether.

That's the foundation you have set up. So please try to focus on making those 30-40 minute games as balanced and enjoyable as possible and stop fretting over length.

I have the same feeling. In an attempt to shorten games it is possible to reach such extremes that one single teamfight would decide the entire game (and we are not exactly far from that situation).

I picked up League in season 3 and liked it because of how it had multiple layers and components, and  now some of them are being trivialized. One of examples is long laning phase with trading that I enjoyed so much as a support player. Currently it is transformed into a 4-5 man bot fiesta that ends shortly after 10 minute mark. Remember when we had a "200 cs at 20 minutes" mark to achieve? Good luck getting this score in the current meta. I get that farming for 20 minutes may sound like a chore, but in the meantime it allowed for some strategic planning for both junglers and laners.

Funny thing is, we "are" in a tank meta.

{{champion:268}} {{champion:13}} {{champion:67}} {{champion:161}} {{champion:222}} should be top tier picks.

They can't because to be top tier right now they also need to be stronger early, which completely breaks them (shit vayne deals with squishies better than tanks right now by IE-Shiv 3 shotting them off huge AD+empowered autos)
Why would Ryze be strong in a tank meta? A tank Meta makes Ryze incredibly easy to lock down with CC and burst him. His range isn't good enough, at least Azir could truly stay on the back line.

The difference is Ryze has to be in the thick of it to really do much and that means he is as vulnerable as the frontliners while being squishier. meanwhile champs like jinx and vel can sit in the back and still contribute quite a bit. The only reason I would put Vayne in this list is her max% hp true damage.

I feel like Jinx IS a top tier adc right now.

Sure she isn't the limelight like Twitch right now, but at least in my games I am having wild success with her right now.
I have a 50% win rate on Azir, doesn't mean he's balanced

We are in "that situation" already.

A misplaced teamfight around 15 minute mark is enough to lose an entire lane worth of towers and an inhibitor depending on intervals in which the enemy players were killed.

The reason games reach 30 minute mark is because people dick around dancing around baron or dragon, where they could simply zerg rush a different lane just like they did the first one, except easier, because somebody HAS to defend from supers.

Not to mention this utterly retarded minion pushing mechanic basically preventing the losing team from creating any pressure without manually and physically dragging minions to the enemy tower.

_"But it helps the losing team to get more gold!"_

I don't fucking need gold when the enemy team is raping my inhibitor for fuck's sake.
I love long games. The back and forth. The small mistakes making the game. 40 minutes with the final 10 being the tense shit. I live for it. Too bad I get one of those maybe one in 30 games.

I'll be blunt.

_**The longer the match, the less I play the game.**_

Not everyone always has 1 hour+ of time to fully dedicate to a videogame. In fact, if you can constantly find a hour to absolutely dedicate to a match, it means you're doing something wrong with your life and you should stop and consider how come you can always find so much time for ONE videogame match.

I love League, but match length is a big turnoff.

After the match clocks at 30+ minutes, I start to get a little frisky. At 40+ minutes I just want it to be over.

 I understand this is a game mostly played by an underage demographic who still has not acquired the concept of time. When you're so young, it often feels like you have all the time of the world, and hanging out with people or studying always seem like stuff you can do later.

So I'm expecting downvotes on this comment. But what can I say. Riot will ultimately do as they see fit, but there is a reason why Blizzard and other modern mobas are honing the length of the match so it doesn't feel like a chore.

You'd die if you knew that in beta, games lasted 60-90 minutes on average and were fun for it's entirety.  Each game was like an hour long RPG rather than a 20 minute kill fest.  It sounds like you would enjoy Bloodline Champions or whatever it's current remake is called, those games are over in minutes.  Saying people are doing something wrong with their life by finding time to play a video game, I'd say they are more in control of their lives.  It's your time, spend it how you want, but league was not designed to be fast and the catering to this more...casual play-style has hurt the games longevity, in my opinion.

So, a game is "casual" if it lasts less than 30 minutes?
You seem to confuse complexity with sheer tedious length.

Look back at the very first few MOBAs to be created. The ones that stem from a Warcraft mod and took at least an hour to finish one game. Those defined what a MOBA is supposed to be. Games like Age of Empires, Command & Conquer, and Starcraft are also MOBAs and they take at least an hour to complete a match because that's what makes them fun. 

The ones you see that don't go past 20/30 minutes are victims of the 20-minute-MOBA craze. MOBAs that are made to finish in a small amount of time because people demand it. Some people don't like long games because it's simply not their interest, but they play it anyways because it's popular ala League of Legends and MOBAs being the next big hit right now. League games only began to become shorter when its Esports scene began to pick up, thus the game becoming more popular. People demanded the game to become more flashy and less boring, so Riot did that and created insane burst metas and awful matchmaking in Season 5 and 6 to quicken match times.

Any sport gets boring when you already know the outcome before had, and the LCS is like that now. Used to watch it 2 years ago, but since last year everything became predictable and got boring. That's just killing the dead, at this point.

I disagree with one thing.

In the beginning of a League game, there IS a teamfight. It's the potential teamfight that comes from an invade. Well, by LCS strategic terms, anyway.

Besides that tiny, miniscule, almost non-related detail, this is true. Making games by default shorter makes Summoner's Rift, a map that is big because things NEED to be slower, not much different than a game of Blood Moon in pace. 

Before we used to say it was funny to end a game that short after a massive snowball. Now it's become the norm and it undermines the value of strategy and defence.
Yeah, short games don't allow for catchup.

I agree with the conclusion here. Structurally, League is not built for short games, and currently Riot's way of accelerating them has come at a major cost in fairness, as matches are much more snowbally and often feel one-sided as a result. The only way to accelerate the game in a healthy manner would be to alter more fundamental systems, i.e. structures, leveling, itemization, etc., all of which I think could use an update, but which could require a vast amount of work and would be very risky. The better move in the meantime I feel should be to accelerate other game modes, namely TT, ARAM, and the RGM set, so that they offer bite-sized fun in contrast to Summoner's Rift's full-course meal. There currently is a bit of a time difference, but I'm not sure it's significant enough, particularly in ARAM where matches can drag on for too long in certain phases.
